item.title: SPECTRA: Spectral Target-Aware Graph Augmentation for Imbalanced Molecular Property Regression
item.description: arXiv:2511.04838v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: In molecular property prediction, the most valuable compounds (e.g., high potency) often occupy sparse regions of the target space. Standard Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) commonly optimize for the average error, underperforming on these uncommon but critical cases, with existing oversampling methods often distorting molecular topology. In this paper, we introduce SPECTRA, a Spectral Target-Aware graph augmentation framework that generates realistic molecular graphs in the spectral domain. SPECTRA (i) reconstructs multi-attribute molecular graphs from SMILES; (ii) aligns molecule pairs via (Fused) Gromov-Wasserstein couplings to obtain node correspondences; (iii) interpolates Laplacian eigenvalues, eigenvectors and node features in a stable share-basis; and (iv) reconstructs edges to synthesize physically plausible intermediates with interpolated targets. A rarity-aware budgeting scheme, derived from a kernel density estimation of labels, concentrates augmentation where data are scarce. Coupled with a spectral GNN using edge-aware Chebyshev convolutions, SPECTRA densifies underrepresented regions without degrading global accuracy. On benchmarks, SPECTRA consistently improves error in relevant target ranges while maintaining competitive overall MAE, and yields interpretable synthetic molecules whose structure reflects the underlying spectral geometry. Our results demonstrate that spectral, geometry-aware augmentation is an effective and efficient strategy for imbalanced molecular property regression.
item.dc:creator: Brenda Nogueira, Meng Jiang, Nitesh V. Chawla, Nuno Moniz

item.title: Hitting Time Distributions of Random Walks on Finite Graphs
item.description: arXiv:2511.04985v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: We investigate the hitting times of random walks on graphs, where a hitting time is defined as the number of steps required for a random walker to move from one node to another. While much of the existing literature focuses on calculating or bounding expected hitting times, this approach is insufficient, as hitting time distributions often exhibit high variance. To address this gap, we analyze both the full distributions and variances of hitting times. Using general Markov chain techniques, as well as Fourier and spectral methods, we derive formulas and recurrence relations for computing these distributions. This is a preliminary work, and some results are being refined. A journal version will be available soon.
item.dc:creator: Anuraag Kumar

item.title: Random Schr\"odinger operator with singular potentials
item.description: arXiv:2511.03183v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: We survey the localization theory of random Schr\"odinger operators with singular single-site distributions, focusing on two regimes: (i) H\"older-continuous laws, where quantitative Wegner estimates enable the classical multiscale analysis (MSA); and (ii) purely atomic (Bernoulli) laws, where the failure of spectral averaging is overcome via quantitative unique continuation principles (UCP). Our discussion covers both lattice and continuum settings and highlights the analytic and combinatorial mechanisms that replace regularity of the single-site measure.
